The Dirichlet problem for the minimal surface equation
in higher dimensions
By Howard Jenkins and James Serrin at Minneapolis
Let D be a bounded domain in the Euclidean space £ ",  with boundary Г,  The Dirichlet problem for the minimal surface equation in D consists in determining a function и = u { x ) ^ which in the domain S satisfies the minimal surface equation

and which continuously takes on given boundary values / on Г,  Here x = ( x^, , . .  j x^ ) denotes points of £ * *,  the subscript notation for partial differentiation has been employed,  and repeated indices are to be summed from 1 to n.  If.  ^ is a class of functions defined on Д the Dirichlet problem is said to be well posed for boundary data in the class ^ if it is uniquely solvable for any given function / in # ". 
When гг = 2 it is well known that a solution of the Dirichlet problem exists for arbitrary continuous boundary data,  provided the domain D is convex.  Proofs of this fact were given in successively increasing generality by Bernstein ( 1910 ) and Haar ( 1927 ),  and the full result was obtained by Rado ( 1930 ).  In a recent paper the present authors gave another proof,  in many ways simpler than that of Rado.  That the Dirichlet problem is not necessarily solvable when D is non - convex was pointed out by Bernstein,  and in fact Finn ( 1965 ) has definitively shown that for every non - convex domain there exists continuous boundary data for which Dirichlet's problem is not solvable.  From the results just noted,  it follows that when n = 2 the Dirichlet problem in D is well posed for arbitrary continuous boundary data if and only if D is convex ( this formulation was suggested by R.  Osserman ). 
In higher dimensions it has generally been assumed that convexity would continue to be a necessary condition for the Dirichlet problem to be well posed for arbitrary data ( see for example the remarks in [ 6 ],  page 152 ).  This assumption in fact plays an important role in the work of Gilbarg and of Stampacchia,  where the existence of solutions for n > 2 is established for smooth boundary data and strictly convex smoothly bounded domains.  We shall show here,  however,  that convexity of the domain is not the appropriate generalization of the two dimensional situation^ but rather it is the mean curvature of the boundary which is crucial. 
More specifically,  let D be a domain in E " whose boundary Г is of class C^ The sign of the mean curvature of the boundary is then fixed by choosing an orientation for the normal vector on Г ; for definiteness we take this to be directed into D.  ( Thus,  for example,  a sphere will have constant positive mean curvature.  ) The following result then holds.
